It's a complicated issue, because what constitutes a "Christian film"? Lord of the Rings is inspired by Christian ideology and beliefs, but it isn't ABOUT those ideas directly. No, Christians (including myself as a Christian) don't win people over by vilifying people with different beliefs. Look at the TV show Firefly and the following movie, Serenity; Joss Whedon is an atheist, but Shepard Book is perhaps the biggest moral center in the entire show. Book is hinted to have an even darker past than anyone else on the show, but he's never turned into a cliche or a cardboard cutout that insults everything Christians are about. Even Joss Whedon in The Avengers where Cap directly says "there's only one God, Ma'am, and I don't think he dresses like that." It's important to see that these are people first and not merely mouth-pieces for ideologies.
I think to be a truly "Christian" film, it should confront the issues held by Christians. Examining them that includes the "why" and "how", as well as its impact.
Outside of the list of recommendations already mentioned, I'd suggest two unorthodox films - "The Book of Eli" and the 2002 film adaptation of "The Count of Monte Cristo". The first deals with a violent man in a post-apocalyptic landscape pressing forward with faith and belief, but using extreme violence to do so, and struggles with his understanding of what his belief is about to justify it. "Monte Cristo" (just as a refresher) is about a wrongfully imprisoned man who loses his faith in God and instead dedicates his life to the vengeance he craves for the wrongs done upon him, but can't seem to shake God from his life. The similarity between these two stories is that they're both about protagonists who contend with their faith, what it means to them, and how they go about 'embracing' that faith. They're not merely conforming to the beliefs of strict Christians and are rewarded for it. They wrestle with these issues and try to find meaning, especially when neither of these men experience a "simple life" that easily conforms to a Christian life.
The problem is how do you define what a Christian movie is? The Lord of the rings is very much in spired by Christian doctrine, but it's not a direct Christian movie. Does that count?

For myself, I was raised Catholic and questioned my views when I went into college. Especially with the allegations and scandals that arose from the child molestation stories surrounding the Catholic Church, I started to drift from the flock, so to speak. For myself, I turned to knowledge concerning the religion. Christian apologetics from intelligent people like John Lennox , Books like the case for Christ, looking over the historocity of the Bible and how it matches archaeological discoveries made afterwords, and the list of intelligent dissections of historical evidence (like third party sources citing Christ' existence) has made me a complete believer from the evidence presented.
Also, it's important to challenge those believes rather than maintain comfort in the early excepting them. Listen to debates. Ask questions. Never settle for merely accepting what you've been taught.

Bible said we needed to love our God with all of our mind, so that means loving science. John Lennox made a great distinction between God and science by comparing it to The creation of the model T. Who built the car? Mechanical engineering, or henry ford? Just because Science exists doesn't disapprove the agent that created the method.

Because I believe in punishing people responsible of grave crimes, especially against the innocent.
I appreciate your honesty but your views are so incredibly callous and appalling that I can't continue this. I hope you change your mind someday.
I appreciate your honesty, but your views are disgusting in supporting killing innocent babies.

that positions seems to be fairly consistent but a moral monstrosity by completely erasing the bodily rights and desires of the woman.
I wouldn't say that it's a moral monstrosity at all. I believe that it is a life, and I side with Ben Shapiro on the issue and in terms of when the baby is considered "alive" and the lack of clarity in terms of defining WHEN it's alive:
"How about week 15, when the baby has an adults taste buds?" he asked. "How about weeks nine and ten when the babys teeth are already beginning to form? Its fingernails are already beginning to develop. Were talking about two months old, right? The baby can turn its head and frown. The baby can hiccup. Is that okay to kill?" How about day 22? The hearts already beating with the childs blood, which may be of a different blood type than the mother," stated Shapiro."
I don't believe in infringing upon someone's individual rights UNLESS that freedom endangers someone else's very life, and I consider that baby alive. In my point of view, it's not self-contradictory but a consistent basis for freedom and rights for a human being.
Yeah, it sucks if someone gets pregnant and they didn't want to get pregnant (which is the majority of abortions). I personally believe that those pregnancies should be carried to term, with government financially helping the woman in question, and then given up for adoption if the mother doesn't want the child. For the issue of rape, as horrifying as it is, it's still a life that you're ending if you choose aborting that fetus. I would instead have the rapists either killed or chemically castrated if found guilty to deter rape in the society.
I find a more abhorrent defense of abortion being that someone's individual liberties are more important than ending a life. You probably don't share that opinion, but that's how I genuinely feel.

You claim religion to be horrendous and vile, yet you don't seem to understand history in that organizations and governments pushing state atheism/secularism have led to some of the worst atrocities in human history. It would be intellectually dishonest if I said that the worst of people who believe in atheism are inherently the same as the best of people who believe in atheism.

Try, though probably impossible for someone like you, to understand that religion doesn't inherently make a person worse or better than the next person.

So if a fetus were declared a person in the legal sense (they're not currently persons according to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personhood#United_States), it would be granted some rights (but not duties, since we can't really ask it to do them), such as perhaps the right to not be aborted.
On that note, is a 15 year old "less" of a person because they don't get the same rights as a 30 year old? This isn't to provoke an argument, just a thought process I'm having.
So, does a baby need to be able to survive outside a womb to be a person?

Well, that's absolutely bigoted and close-minded, especially when most laws and morals concerning universal and inalienable human rights are from the Bible.
Also, question out of curiosity are all religions the same, and just as dangerous? What about Buddhists? Are they all a pack of deplorables? Are all Christians dangerous? Are peace-loving quakers the same thing as a Protestant? Are all Jews a bad influence on society? Are the Catholic churches investment in science and education a bad thing for the development of the Western world?

Uh....well, actually, here's some readings against slavery in the Bible, [example](http://christianapologeticsalliance.com/2012/10/20/you-say-the-bible-advocates-slavery/), [other example](https://carm.org/slavery), [last example](http://apologeticspress.org/apcontent.aspx?category=6 article=1587).
Not to mention "antebellum slavery" was not the same as concept as "Greek slavery".
And for stoning, a lot of philosophers and historians side more with the idea that the law was meant to discourage acts that were found to be sinful: [example](http://www.equip.org/article/stoning-adulterers/)
Also, blaming bad morals from the Bible is like blaming the Gulags of Joseph Stalin and the USSR with Pol Pot and Mao Zedong's genocide against the religious as a direct influence of state atheism/secularism. It's ludicrous for thinking a particular brand of ideas make people bad, and not the people themselves.

Cells don't have rights. If it cannot exist outside of the womb, it is not a person.
Is a person only a person when it's born? What about at 8 1/2 months?

Religion shouldn't be the basis upon which we create our laws.
Well, then there goes "inalienable human rights":
Does the denial of God have any entailments? Yes, it does: take just one examplethe concept of human rights. Modern human rights theory is based on the Judeo-Christian idea that human beings are of tremendous value and worth, because they are made in the image of God. Reject God and suddenly you have to start again, explaining why one particular creature, thrown up by the forces of time, chance and natural selection mixing and chopping atoms and chemicals for several billion years possesses inalienable rights, whereas amoeba, aardvarks and eggplants do not. Many philosophers and thinkers recognise the problem and are honest enough to admit if you dismiss God, you lose many other things, too.

but saying that religion doesn't have much to do with it is being willfully ignorant.
That's just intellectually dishonest. There are people who are not religious who believe that a life begins at conception, or even far earlier than some groups would like to advocate for.

We dont have to wonder about when to apply human rights. They already protect the mother from having her womb not belong to her for 9 months.
The argument is that you are killing a human being in the womb, and that people don't have the right to end another's life if it's not endangering them. It's a far more complex issue than that.

WRITING.TITLE: What's the difference between an archetype and a stereotype?
One of my favorite openings to any story across the spectrum of all media (games, movies, TV, etc.)
Should we stick with the same brand of video camera?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello everyone. My company is thinking about acquiring another video camera to record professional events. Currently, we have a Canon VIXIA HF G10, and I'm researching the Canon XA10 in terms of camera quality that is "similar" to the G10 (as we want to have the visual fidelity of both cameras to be as close to the same as possible as we want a consistent visual look for our footage, so "better" cameras might be out of the question).
We're trying to find a camera to fill that role, but we were also wondering if we should stick with a Canon camera, or try and branch out to another brand. Are there any added benefits of sticking with the same brand of camera?
Thank you for taking the time to read this thread.

WRITING.TITLE: Is God Great? Christopher Hitchens vs. Professor John Lennox (an intellectual stimulating debate that personally strengthened my own beliefs).
What do you consider to be a "Horror movie"?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hey everyone,
I was rewatching "Aliens" over the weekend, then decided to watch "Jurassic Park" after that, and it got me wondering. What is a "horror film"? Are both of these movies horror related? If not, why not? Do horror films need to have certain staplemarks? Does it just need to be scary some of the time, or most of the time? Can a "true horror film" be PG-13? Can it be a genre mash-up, or does it need to stand as the primary defining feature of the movie?
I wanted to see what you all thought and give your opinions and insight into how you define a "horror film."

WRITING.TITLE: Was anyone else surprised with how fast the editing was in Shin Godzilla?
WRITING.TEXT:
Not that I'm complaining because they used it to great effect, but I was watching the film last night and I was noticing just how quick the editing was with so many different cuts.
It reminded me a lot of Dark City they cut so frequently (once again, I don't have an inherent problem with it as I ALSO loved that movie).
Did anyone else feel this way when watching it?

Favorite line from a bad film?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hey, everyone.
We all have our favorite lines from great movies, but what about great lines from bad films? I know we all have different definitions of what "bad" could be, but, in my eyes, these would be examples of pieces of great writing in an otherwise unremarkable or downright awful film that for whatever reason managed to have a great piece of dialog.
For myself, I'm going to have to go with Street Fighter:
"For you, the day Bison graced your village was the most important day of your life. But for me, it was Tuesday."
